Nikhil Srinivasan and Christian Keller discuss the economy and politics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

NIKHIL SRINIVASAN, CHAIRMAN INTERNATIONAL, HPS INVESTMENT PARTNERS; AND CHRISTIAN KELLER, HEAD OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, BARCLAYS; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

OCTOBER 02, 2017

SPEAKERS: NIKHIL SRINIVASAN, CHAIRMAN INTERNATIONAL, HPS INVESTMENT PARTNERS

CHRISTIAN KELLER, HEAD OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, BARCLAYS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Now, joining us this morning are Christian Keller, he's head of economic research at Barclays, and Nikhil Srinivasan, he's chairman international at HPS Investment Partners. Nikhil manages $42 billion and is the former group chief investment officer at Assicurazioni Generali. I think it took me at the time, like four years, Nikhil, to get you back on, so I'm glad you're more available to us now, thank you for coming on.

NIKHIL SRINIVASAN, CHAIRMAN INTERNATIONAL, HPS INVESTMENT PARTNERS: Thank you, Francine, it's my pleasure.

LACQUA: And Christian, thank you for -- for coming on as well. first of all, how should investors look at risk Catalonia? So this is something that was ignored on Friday, and then today, it seems that even spreads between the German and Italian yields are going a little bit crazy.

SRINIVASAN: You get -- you have to get used to a bit of volatility in this. I think there's a process, and I think your colleague in Barcelona had some comments. My point of view, this request constitutional reform, and that'll take a bit of time, and then at some point then, the Catalonians will decide will they want to vote again based on the reform. So until that happens, that could take several months, it's going to be a bit unsaid, but it's not going to be dramatically bad, I mean, Spanish yields are up seven basis points, and I wouldn't say that's a calamity.

LACQUA: No, it's not a calamity, but when you look at the ECB and kind of, you know, the fact that they are standing firm, the fact that you see this kind of news, Christian, what does it mean for Spanish GDP overall?

CHRISTIAN KELLER, HEAD OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, BARCLAYS: Well, I mean Catalonia as well, very much reported, is 1/5 of the Spanish economy, so it is an important part, but so far, I would actually be of a similar view that, you know, cyclically, Europe looks quite strong right now, you know, and then we have a global recovery that in -- in full swing, we have a synchronized recovery in Europe after, you know, the elections in France which is more of a, you know, real problem early in December or could have been one, and then you had actually, Italy and Spain in particular, cleaning up the bank balance sheet, so now, we have a situation where really, Europe, you know, looks quite good with regard to growth, and I'm not sure whether this -- of course, we have to see how far, you know, this -- this expands now, but this will really be something that will more seriously, fundamentally in a way, derail this recovery that we see in Europe.

LACQUA: Nikhil, you were saying that basically, when you look at the Spanish bonds, they're falling a touch, but it's nothing to (inaudible) about. Let me bring you over to my chart. This is -- you see the Spanish bonds compared to the Catalonian bonds. For our radio listeners, we will push it out on social media. Any value? I'm not necessarily talking to you about, you know, Catalonian bonds, but any value in European bonds at the moment?

SRINIVASAN: Sure. I mean, look, I mean, what is the Catalonian situation? This is a remnant of the recession, 2008. You could argue that the central bank in Europe, the ECB, should have reacted faster, they didn't. You have in equity in Europe, and you see that through the German election, you see that now through the Catalonian failed election or failed independence vote. I'd say that you have to continue to be loose in Europe in terms of monetary policy, so any tightening, any -- any tapering that the ECB comes up will have to be minor, won't be significant (inaudible), so if spreads blow out a bit -- a bit more, blow out, meaning -- it's a strong word, the spreads widen a bit more, I'd be a buyer.

LACQUA: OK. This is what we're looking at in terms of spreads for example, between the Italian and Spanish 10-year yield. Christian, how should we view the German elections, the fact that actually, Wolfgang Schaeuble, who's an institution, resigned to make place for someone else partly because of this new coalition being formed, and what do you make of the Italian elections? Is that the biggest risk going forward?

KELLER: Yes. I think until maybe, the development of the last few days, we have to maybe reassess how -- how far this constitutional crisis in Spain can go, but so -- until now, we always thought the Italian elections coming sometime early next year, were the biggest remaining risk in Europe. In -- in Germany, I think, look, Ms. Merkel is clearly weakened, and I think what it -- how it will -- it will affect a little bit, the fact that these markets have developed about a new German-French access and how much Germany would be willing to share risk possibly in, you know, in further integration of the European Union. On the finance ministry, we will see a different phase. I doubt that we will see a strong change in policy because the likely new minister from the Free Democrats, FDP will probably not be that different from Schaeuble when it comes to policies and attitudes towards risk sharing.

LACQUA: Nikhil, what would it take for you to buy Italian yields, Italian bonds?

SRINIVASAN: Italian bonds have rallied quite a bit in the last few months. Now probably, I would like a little bit of a spread blow out again in Italy. I don't -- I'm not so worried about the Italian election as other people are (inaudible).

LACQUA: Why not?

SRINIVASAN: Well, Italy has created about a million jobs in the last three years, GDP is running to one and a half as opposed to expectation which is below one. I think we -- we don't know how the coalition is going to be formed, it's still too early to tell, but I think that things chug along in Italy. I mean, there are still some long-term -- there are definite long- term concerns, but in the short term, it looks all right, so again, if -- if Italian yields as a -- as a consequence of what's happening in Spain also move out a bit, I'd be a buyer of Italian bonds as well.

LACQUA: Do you think, Nikhil, that Mario Draghi wakes up this morning and looks at these yields and kind of tries to process, you know, what the Catalonia vote and the upcoming Italian elections mean for his policy?

SRINIVASAN: Well, it's not just the Catalonia vote, I think he is already (inaudible) I don't know if he has done it directly, but other people in the ECB have -- have hinted the market, they will be pulling back but not significantly, they've got to do that, pull back but not significantly, because you must remember, and I -- I go back to this, Catalonia, German elections, all this is a consequence of tight monetary policy when they could have loosened, OK? They took their time to do it. Now, they've got to take their time to pull back.

LACQUA: OK, interesting. Nikhil and Christian both stay with us. Christian Keller there and Nikhil, Srinivasan.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Well, still with us are Christian Keller from Barclays and Nikhil Srinivasan from HPS Investment Partners. Thank you both for sticking around. Christian, let me go to you on Brexit. What do we know, what do we -- it seems messy, right? Is this part and parcel of negotiations or is it more messier than needed?

KELLER: It's unprecedented. We -- we really have no comparison, right, but I think what is clear that the E.U. was in a -- negotiating from a position of strength, you know, they had no -- you know, they had no reason to really be upfront with, you know, approaching the U.K., they're waiting for the U.K. I think the speech in Florence was very important. I think she touched upon all the outstanding issues. Obviously, she couldn't deliver the details yet that some would have wanted, but the -- the reception in a way on the continent I think was -- was positive. You heard Michel Barnier speaking a few words of English, I think, you know, that is a good sign, and now --

LACQUA: Always a good sign.

KELLER: And now, I think it's -- it's really up this -- up to do this week because people will watch whether her concept that she alluded to in the Florence speech basically has a strong backing by her own party. And she must come out of this week in a way as someone who is, you know, sure to be the leader for the coming years, and then I think Brexit could take a more, you know, constructive path than it has maybe over the last past few months.

LACQUA: Christian, when you revise upwards or downwards your economic forecast for the U.K., do you look at BOE or do you look at Brexit talks, or both?

KELLER: We -- we look more at -- at Brexit talks in the sense that we look at uncertainty and what could happen to investment. At the moment, you know, we have a U.K. economy that has been much more resilient than people have thought. And you know, consumption has held up very well, and what we see now is, you know, investment in a way, slowing, and you know, the BOE will be important, they may be hiking, and that has an impact on the -- on consumers who pay mortgages, et cetera, but I think if we have an outlook for Brexit that signal some kind of a certainty, I think that would help the U.K. economy over the medium term significantly.

LACQUA: Have you -- are you a political analyst yet? You know, forget all this investment stuff.

SRINIVASAN: I can do politics.

LACQUA: Politics, right. Do you need to be like a political analyst to try figure out where you put money in the -- in the U.K. or in the U.S., or not?

SRINIVASAN: No, absolutely. But I think on Brexit, Christian has all the points right, I don't disagree with anything he said. My point is that, it's a complex issue, negotiating Brexit. I think you have to be incrementalist (ph) about it just because the Europeans are and the whole process is. And don't forget that Britain had about a 15-year up-cycle, barring that '07, '08 situation. So just from a cyclical point of view, having a slower U.K. is expected, and now, doesn't mean it's going to collapse, I just think they just expect slower growth in the U.K.

LACQUA: What happens to pound? And actually, if pound is weaker, does it make, you know, investments more attractive?

SRINIVASAN: Yes, pound was in a 1.20, 1.30 range, it's now broken out to 1.33, 1.34, I think it stays around here, and (inaudible) it pulled back a bit, but I think you've got a sterling which is essentially trying to find a base around 1.30, you know, 1.28, 1.30.

LACQUA: OK. 1.28, 1.30. Christian, first of all, what's your take on -- this is actually one of my favorite charts, and this is U.K. consumer credit, and it's something that I imagine Mark Carney is looking at very closely because of interest rates and the fact that households are so indebted in this country, does this chart worry you?

KELLER: Well, it is a chart that is important, and I think it is important also because it is behind some of the recent significant change in the attitude of the Bank of England. And if you go through particularly, what some of the MPC members who are considered to be dovish when they turn around in their view, they highlighted a balance sheet of the households and said, deleveraging of -- of households was over, and they have been leveraging, and this is why they argued for a rate hike because they believed they're now in a situation where households are level again, households are robust enough that they could withstand, you know, some increase in interest rates. So I think it's a very important chart and one -- one to follow. Not concerned really, I think, you know, the hikes will be -- we see one hike for now, you know, and I think the Bank of England will -- will act very, very cautiously.

LACQUA: OK. What's your take on -- on euro-pound actually? So you gave us a level on euro-dollar, is this the most interesting one?

SRINIVASAN: Yes, range bound, just range bound. Like a lot of currency, I think euro-dollar will be range bound, euro-sterling is range bound, I think you've got -- you got a period of uncertainty, in the U.K. it's Brexit, in Europe now, it's got Spain, Catalonia, et cetera, and of course, ECB policy, so I think between both things, I think you really got a range bound currency across.

LACQUA: OK. Interesting. I want to talk a little bit more about the global outlook now. Now, in a new report, Barclays has said U.S. growth remains decent if unexciting, while Europe and Japan have shown further upside. The bank expects the Fed to hike in December and twice in 2018, while the ECB is likely to taper further next year. Christian, this is your report, what's the most surprising thing in it?

KELLER: I think the most surprising in it is if you -- if you look at it again, you know, how well global growth is synchronized. And, you know, there's a lot of questions from investors who say, well, is this as good as it gets? You know, shouldn't one be more cautious now? You know, things have been going very well in particular, if -- if you look at equity valuation in the U.S. But we look at the data, and we see a global economy that continues to expand, where U.S. no longer the cyclical leadership, but we get very good data out of -- out of Europe. Japan's in the economy that has relatively low growth but is running above potential. We see some of the emerging markets like Russia, Brazil, coming out of deep recessions, and we see a China that you saw it over -- over the weekend, continues to hold up quite well. Now, this is something we haven't had for 5, 6 years, and it means, global growth running around 4 percent, and if you look at equity earnings, they correlate very well with global growth, and we think that is basically the -- the big story that is still there, and that's why we continue to be quite constructive.

LACQUA: Are -- are you -- are you positive about world growth or is it all based on air?

SRINIVASAN: This is the first time since 2007 that all -- all economies, 40 plus economies counted by the OECD, are showing positive growth, so I am very comfortable with growth.

LACQUA: How do you feel with inflation though? I| mean, there are -- there are still puzzles, right? And I don't know if it's the Phillips curve being broken or something more sinister out there.

KELLER: I think, you know, the -- the second part of the surprise is the - - in the data is basically that inflation stays so muted. The good thing is we are creating drops, so unemployment rates are falling in all the key economies, but we don't have the wage growth. Now, whether it's something sinister, I think there are several effect at work, one, it does take time. People are coming back into the labor market, you mentioned Italy earlier. There are people now coming back who were not in the Labor market, that's where the unemployment doesn't fall, because if the participation rates goes up. These are good developments, but I think there is something bigger in the background, that's technology, globalization, and that's why Phillips curves no longer work the way they did in the past, and that's something I think central banks have to grapple with because all their models and all their usual actions are based on, you know, the Phillips curve working.

LACQUA: And Nikhil, do you worry -- I don't know if you worry about inflation or do you just worry that for example, if you look at the most distorted market (inaudible) most probably the bond market, and so as this kind of, you know, gets re-priced, it could lead to further correction (inaudible).

SRINIVASAN: Yes, let's talk about this -- this inflation and this Fed policy, for example. Fed policy is all about normalization. I don't think that it really cares much about inflation as normalizing the interest rate situation.

LACQUA: OK. But should they care more about inflation?

SRINIVASAN: Well, they -- they want inflation. I think everything -- OK, if you look at global, you look at reflationary currencies, Aussie dollar, Canadian dollar, basic materials, copper, aluminum, all are pointing to more inflation, OK? We haven't seen it in the U.S., we haven't really seen it anywhere in the world right now, but at least --

LACQUA: Except for U.K.

SRINIVASAN: Yes. But things -- if I -- if I look at typical reflationary indicators are all up, but I said, the Feds behavior is about normalizing based on financial stability, it's not really based on well, inflation's going to hit X, and so we've got to do it now. And so the Fed will continue to gradually increase rates, OK? I think we'll get some inflation, probably get some inflation in Germany, it's been going very strong, probably get some inflation generally, in Europe, probably get some everywhere, but we're not going to get as much as people want, so when you look at yields and you say, OK, well, yields are 10-year U.S. at 2.36 today, where is it going? Look, it will go higher. I think all yields were high in the next 12 months.

LACQUA: All right. Guys, thank you so much. Christian Keller there, head of economic research at Barclays, thank you for your time. And Nikhil Srinivasan stays with us, we'll talk a little bit more about the risks out there, we had great comments from Crispin Odey as well. We'll talk about regulation and kind of China as well next.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Well, still with us, Nikhil Srinivasan, he is from HPS Investment Partners. Nikhil, when you look at the risks out there, so we had Mr. Odey actually quite bearish overall, right, about his view on the world economy. What do you see as the biggest risk out there for markets?

SRINIVASAN: I think the biggest risk, Francine, is complacency. I think people are complacent about the North Korean situation, they're complacent about the Middle East and the Kyrgyzstan independence vote and oil in general, and they're complacent in the U.S. about increased regulation on big Tech. So I think if you look everywhere, I think the biggest risk is complacency. People are saying, well, let's just keep going forward.

LACQUA: Why are they complacent? Is it something to do with algorithms and the way that the markets are actually right at the moment, or is it that it's impossible to, you know, price in Trump's next move, but also you're going to do with North Korea?

SRINIVASAN: Well, it's hard to value the level of risk that I'm talking about. So given it's hard to value the risk, given there's a lot of liquidity out there, given the Fed's policies, you know, I'd say that people just want to continue doing what they're doing and they've made money doing it, so you can't argue with that, right? So these are, if you ask me, the biggest risk is complacency because it's not priced in. Korea, it's not pricing in Korean risk.

LACQUA: What will it take to be priced in? I mean, is it kind of a snowball effect?

SRINIVASAN: Well, not necessarily. For example, if you are in the Big Tech stocks for example, I think they are not people -- they have come off a bit, I mean, they've come off relative to the market. I think people have to get used to the fact that these companies are going to face more of a (inaudible) going forward, but the ownership of these stocks remains extremely robust, and so you haven't seen a real selloff, 10 percent, but you haven't seen a real selloff for these companies yet, that's one thing.

LACQUA: Nikhil, do you worry about -- I mean, I don't know what actually your canary in the coal mine, you know, benchmark is, is there something? Will it come from China, or is it really impossible to predict?

SRINIVASAN: China's fine, Francine. So if you're talking about China, I think people shouldn't worry about China, they --

LACQUA: Not even the debt --

SRINIVASAN: No, nothing.

LACQUA: -- and reserves?

SRINIVASAN: Nothing. I think the currency has shown resilience, currency rallied in the last few weeks. I think the congress is going to go fine, I think you're going to have a slowdown of growth built in because of supply- side reform so they have -- have kicked in, built in because you have this anti-corruption move which is going to taper off. I think going into next year in the (inaudible) we see very, very growth -- good growth in China, I am not worried about China at all.

LACQUA: Are you worried about emerging markets and the fact that if Fed normalizes? It's been telegraphed for about three years, but are you worried about some kind of correction in emerging markets, just (inaudible) you know, technical Fed?

SRINIVASAN: Yes, well, because they -- they rallied a lot, so yes, they could correct. I mean, certainly, but I think China will continue to go up, and the Chinese market looks pretty good overall. I think all these emerging markets have run up quite a bit, most of them (inaudible). I would say I'm -- I'm less bearish or less worried about corrections from the oil markets like Russia. I think Russia has more upside as well. I think that, you know, you have to take -- take a step back and say, look, are we still looking at the world through the lens of '07, '08? And every time something happens, we can never tell there's a correction coming, corrections will come. Global economy is growing. It think the biggest uncertainties are the three things that I mentioned.

LACQUA: OK. But what about politics? Again, if you look at, you know, people voting in Europe for example, sure, GDP is getting higher, you know, joblessness is going down, but actually, one in 10 people voted for a far right candidate in the -- in Germany, they did the same in France.

SRINIVASAN: Well, there's -- there's economic inequity in Europe, just like it is in another parts of the world. Like, we saw that in the U.S., we're seeing that here as well, that's going to continue, that's not going away.

LACQUA: Will it get worse?

SRINIVASAN: I think it's going to get worse. But it's not going to get substantially worse, it's going to get worse in terms of (inaudible) voting patterns that continue to show people are disgruntled, at least a large or a visible part of the population is disgruntled. It's -- it's disgruntled here in the U.K., in Germany, in Spain, now you see it, in Italy, everywhere and around the world, so you're going to see that. you're going to see protest votes gathering pace. Now, that's going to impact policy, monetary policy, fiscal policy, you're going to see governments having to run deficits. The U.K. government will have to run their deficit. European governments have to run their deficit. Even the German government which is -- which is in surplus will incrementally have to increase spending on infrastructure and other things, incrementally, gradually, step by step, German style. I think everyone has to accept the fact that there are certain people in the population that are not really gaining from what is headline growth.

LACQUA: All right, Nikhil, thank you so much. Nikhil Srinivasan there, chairman international, HPS Investment Partners stays with us.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Now, we were just talking with Nikhil Srinivasan, and we have a question from NIB, from a viewer, and this Nikhil is for you. Now, this is a question, we were talking of course, about complacency and the market's complacency, would you say that the complacency originates from the fact that the majority of the disgruntled are not amongst its players? So actually, does this disgruntlement, Nikhil, then -- then becomes something that we should worry about for markets?

SRINIVASAN: The question is fair. I think (inaudible) players is right. I don't think you have to worry about it is a constant something might happen, but I think it is, the consequence from a policy point of view is governments have to remain relatively loose in the fiscal front, that's it. And on the monetary side, you have to remain loose as well, so that's not - - you know, tightening's not going t to happen, it can't happen if you want the disgruntled to be feeling better off. And I don't think any economy in Europe can tighten today, or in the U.S. I don't think the U.S. can tighten. In fact, the tax cut plans are all going to be fiscally negative, right? Be expansionary, so no, I think fiscal policy has to remain expansionary.

LACQUA: OK. Which is why you were talking about normalizing, and actually, not tightening. The dollar has strengthened after reports that President Trump and secretary -- Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin have met with Kevin Warsh to discuss nominating him to succeed Fed chair, Janet Yellen. Nikhil, again, I guess for you, it doesn't really matter who's in charge next. I seem to understand about your comments that it will be kind of steady as she goes which is normalizing.

SRINIVASAN: Yes. I think my point about normalizing was less to do with inflation even though inflation is -- is the core of the Fed alongside employment, I'd say it's more to do with normalizing in General, to ensure financial stability. Ownership of U.S. equities among U.S. households has again, reached a high last seen 10 years ago, and I think the Fed must be concerned, and they must ensure that they don't have any - any accidents down the road, so I think that normalization is far from close.

LACQUA: Ok. But does it -- it still matters right, if you have someone at the head who's a dove or a hawk, because actually, how you interpret, I mean, you say they shouldn't focus too much on inflation, they just want stability, but so far, inflation has been the cornerstone of how you measure stability.

SRINIVASAN: Yes. But you see, every time they don't get inflation, they use another measure. They try and say, well, it's going to come, they could suddenly surprise you. Look, these are the comments with people who don't see inflation, yet want to raise rates.

LACQUA: OK, would you change the mandate? And if you would change the mandate for the Fed, what would you be looking at? I mean, you need metric, right, on - on how you look at it, otherwise, it's a free for all.

SRINIVASAN: I would look -- I mean, I look at something they can't probably include which is capital allocation because when you have a lot of free liquidity you misallocate capital, and that's what's been happening. You know, certain really been bid up, other things like capital investment has been ignore, so -- but I think you can't really change the mandate, that's not my point. My point is that, we were late to normalize, and now, they have to at least, reach a level of normalization they are comfortable with, which maybe, the market decide if that's too high, too low, but what they are comfortable with, and that means high rates.

LACQUA: Nikhil, what will be a game-changer for you in the U.S.? Is it all to do with monetary policy or does a tax cut for example, repatriation at 10 percent actually, significantly change the way you look at animal spirits U.S.?

SRINIVASAN: I think what would be a game changer if GDP in the U.S. really dropped, say, below 1 percent, which it doesn't seem at this point, likely.

LACQUA: So why would it do that?

SRINIVASAN: Well, because I think people aren't ready for that. People are ready -- people accepted a stable one and a half economy, or one and a half, two. People are not ready for something that comes closer to the zero to one, and I think that would surprise people, and that would show finally that, oh, my god, you know, something is wrong, we're not getting the growth they want, and I think that the --

LACQUA: But you think that's likely, or is --

SRINIVASAN: I don't think that's likely. At today's setting, I don't see it in the numbers. I can't say it's going to happen, but I'm saying that's your risk, you said , what's your biggest risk? That's my biggest risk, is GDP falling below expectation.

LACQUA: OK. But what would need to happen for that GDP to fall below expectations?

SRINIVASAN: Just people don't want to buy consumption falls, I mean, retail spending falls. I mean, these are, you know, oil prices, you know the issue. But again, if oil prices go up significant -- I think oil is in a good spot, I don't see we're going to $80, but I see oil pretty well-bid everywhere.

LACQUA: When you look at infrastructure plans, again, from the Trump administration, does -- does filter through GDP? I mean, it's unclear to me, even these tax cuts, at this point in the cycle, does it filter through inflation, or does it -- or does it work on GDP?

SRINIVASAN: I prefer tax cuts to infrastructure spending. Infrastructure spending is a bit like communism, it works well in theory, not always well in practice.

LACQUA: Because of lagging time?

SRINIVASAN: Just wastage, slippage, all kinds of things, you know. So the dollar spent on infrastructure doesn't really -- studies have shown infrastructure doesn't yield as much for GDP as tax cuts do, so if you ask me which one I'd prefer, I'd prefer tax cuts.

LACQUA: What's priced in at the moment in the market?

SRINIVASAN: I think tax cut, something's -- you -- one, Trump success is priced in, and I think it's going to be somewhat linked to tax cuts, which I think is -- is reasonable. I mean, there may be compromises along the way between the two parties, but I think that he'll get something, I'll be surprised if the president doesn't.

LACQUA: OK. Nikhil, when you look at I guess, the composition, you know, we talked a little bit about around the world, emerging markets, U.S., Europe, is it right to think that Europe will outperform the U.S.? I know we're starting from the very low base.

SRINIVASAN: No, no, for sure. I have no doubt that the -- Europe will (inaudible) the U.S. votes in terms of overall growth and also as well, markets. I'd rather buy European equities than U.S. equities (inaudible).

LACQUA: But equities are exposed globally, so you get, what, you get a discount because of European (inaudible) you?

SRINIVASAN: Well, I mean, yes. I mean, you know, European equities are both global and low, and I just say, baskets of European stocks are more appealing, I think you're going to have a looser policy directive from the ECB, you know, continued loose policy from the ECB, you're going to have continued loose fiscal from European governments, so Europe looks all right. I mean, you know, you can't call the end Europe, yen to Europe just a year after things have started to really dwell or two years (inaudible) a lot of the countries. Germany's been doing well for a long time.

LACQUA: It's Europe. Don't we do that every couple of years that it's the end of the world, and end of the -- end of the -- the experiment?

SRINIVASAN: You know, commentators in this country and the U.S. have been talking about the end of the experiment for a very long time, ever since the crisis, right, they've been wrong, and they're going to continue to be wrong about the end of the experiment, OK? The question then is, can Europe outperform? And Europe's sometimes its own worst enemy. It was too late in terms of loosening monetary policy, you've seen the consequences in Spain yesterday, you know, and so as long as things continue to chug along and, you know, the French-German relationship could just produce positive news for Europe. I think Europe continues to do fine. I think it's -- it's just -- it's a cottage industry to be negative on Europe all the time.

LACQUA: All right, Nikhil, thank you so much for joining us. We have to get you back on to talk about Japan as well, that's the only thing we kind of didn't do in our 60 minutes (inaudible). Nikhil Srinivasan there from HPS Investment Partners.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

NIKHIL SRINIVASAN, CHAIRMAN INTERNATIONAL, HPS INVESTMENT PARTNERS; AND CHRISTIAN KELLER, HEAD OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, BARCLAYS; ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

OCTOBER 02, 2017

SPEAKERS: NIKHIL SRINIVASAN, CHAIRMAN INTERNATIONAL, HPS INVESTMENT PARTNERS

CHRISTIAN KELLER, HEAD OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, BARCLAYS

FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG NEWS

[*] FRANCINE LACQUA, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: Now, joining us this morning are Christian Keller, he's head of economic research at Barclays, and Nikhil Srinivasan, he's chairman international at HPS Investment Partners. Nikhil manages $42 billion and is the former group chief investment officer at Assicurazioni Generali. I think it took me at the time, like four years, Nikhil, to get you back on, so I'm glad you're more available to us now, thank you for coming on.

NIKHIL SRINIVASAN, CHAIRMAN INTERNATIONAL, HPS INVESTMENT PARTNERS: Thank you, Francine, it's my pleasure.

LACQUA: And Christian, thank you for -- for coming on as well. first of all, how should investors look at risk Catalonia? So this is something that was ignored on Friday, and then today, it seems that even spreads between the German and Italian yields are going a little bit crazy.

SRINIVASAN: You get -- you have to get used to a bit of volatility in this. I think there's a process, and I think your colleague in Barcelona had some comments. My point of view, this request constitutional reform, and that'll take a bit of time, and then at some point then, the Catalonians will decide will they want to vote again based on the reform. So until that happens, that could take several months, it's going to be a bit unsaid, but it's not going to be dramatically bad, I mean, Spanish yields are up seven basis points, and I wouldn't say that's a calamity.

LACQUA: No, it's not a calamity, but when you look at the ECB and kind of, you know, the fact that they are standing firm, the fact that you see this kind of news, Christian, what does it mean for Spanish GDP overall?

CHRISTIAN KELLER, HEAD OF ECONOMIC RESEARCH, BARCLAYS: Well, I mean Catalonia as well, very much reported, is 1/5 of the Spanish economy, so it is an important part, but so far, I would actually be of a similar view that, you know, cyclically, Europe looks quite strong right now, you know, and then we have a global recovery that in -- in full swing, we have a synchronized recovery in Europe after, you know, the elections in France which is more of a, you know, real problem early in December or could have been one, and then you had actually, Italy and Spain in particular, cleaning up the bank balance sheet, so now, we have a situation where really, Europe, you know, looks quite good with regard to growth, and I'm not sure whether this -- of course, we have to see how far, you know, this -- this expands now, but this will really be something that will more seriously, fundamentally in a way, derail this recovery that we see in Europe.

LACQUA: Nikhil, you were saying that basically, when you look at the Spanish bonds, they're falling a touch, but it's nothing to (inaudible) about. Let me bring you over to my chart. This is -- you see the Spanish bonds compared to the Catalonian bonds. For our radio listeners, we will push it out on social media. Any value? I'm not necessarily talking to you about, you know, Catalonian bonds, but any value in European bonds at the moment?

SRINIVASAN: Sure. I mean, look, I mean, what is the Catalonian situation? This is a remnant of the recession, 2008. You could argue that the central bank in Europe, the ECB, should have reacted faster, they didn't. You have in equity in Europe, and you see that through the German election, you see that now through the Catalonian failed election or failed independence vote. I'd say that you have to continue to be loose in Europe in terms of monetary policy, so any tightening, any -- any tapering that the ECB comes up will have to be minor, won't be significant (inaudible), so if spreads blow out a bit -- a bit more, blow out, meaning -- it's a strong word, the spreads widen a bit more, I'd be a buyer.

LACQUA: OK. This is what we're looking at in terms of spreads for example, between the Italian and Spanish 10-year yield. Christian, how should we view the German elections, the fact that actually, Wolfgang Schaeuble, who's an institution, resigned to make place for someone else partly because of this new coalition being formed, and what do you make of the Italian elections? Is that the biggest risk going forward?

KELLER: Yes. I think until maybe, the development of the last few days, we have to maybe reassess how -- how far this constitutional crisis in Spain can go, but so -- until now, we always thought the Italian elections coming sometime early next year, were the biggest remaining risk in Europe. In -- in Germany, I think, look, Ms. Merkel is clearly weakened, and I think what it -- how it will -- it will affect a little bit, the fact that these markets have developed about a new German-French access and how much Germany would be willing to share risk possibly in, you know, in further integration of the European Union. On the finance ministry, we will see a different phase. I doubt that we will see a strong change in policy because the likely new minister from the Free Democrats, FDP will probably not be that different from Schaeuble when it comes to policies and attitudes towards risk sharing.

LACQUA: Nikhil, what would it take for you to buy Italian yields, Italian bonds?

SRINIVASAN: Italian bonds have rallied quite a bit in the last few months. Now probably, I would like a little bit of a spread blow out again in Italy. I don't -- I'm not so worried about the Italian election as other people are (inaudible).

LACQUA: Why not?

SRINIVASAN: Well, Italy has created about a million jobs in the last three years, GDP is running to one and a half as opposed to expectation which is below one. I think we -- we don't know how the coalition is going to be formed, it's still too early to tell, but I think that things chug along in Italy. I mean, there are still some long-term -- there are definite long- term concerns, but in the short term, it looks all right, so again, if -- if Italian yields as a -- as a consequence of what's happening in Spain also move out a bit, I'd be a buyer of Italian bonds as well.

LACQUA: Do you think, Nikhil, that Mario Draghi wakes up this morning and looks at these yields and kind of tries to process, you know, what the Catalonia vote and the upcoming Italian elections mean for his policy?

SRINIVASAN: Well, it's not just the Catalonia vote, I think he is already (inaudible) I don't know if he has done it directly, but other people in the ECB have -- have hinted the market, they will be pulling back but not significantly, they've got to do that, pull back but not significantly, because you must remember, and I -- I go back to this, Catalonia, German elections, all this is a consequence of tight monetary policy when they could have loosened, OK? They took their time to do it. Now, they've got to take their time to pull back.

LACQUA: OK, interesting. Nikhil and Christian both stay with us. Christian Keller there and Nikhil, Srinivasan.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Well, still with us are Christian Keller from Barclays and Nikhil Srinivasan from HPS Investment Partners. Thank you both for sticking around. Christian, let me go to you on Brexit. What do we know, what do we -- it seems messy, right? Is this part and parcel of negotiations or is it more messier than needed?

KELLER: It's unprecedented. We -- we really have no comparison, right, but I think what is clear that the E.U. was in a -- negotiating from a position of strength, you know, they had no -- you know, they had no reason to really be upfront with, you know, approaching the U.K., they're waiting for the U.K. I think the speech in Florence was very important. I think she touched upon all the outstanding issues. Obviously, she couldn't deliver the details yet that some would have wanted, but the -- the reception in a way on the continent I think was -- was positive. You heard Michel Barnier speaking a few words of English, I think, you know, that is a good sign, and now --

LACQUA: Always a good sign.

KELLER: And now, I think it's -- it's really up this -- up to do this week because people will watch whether her concept that she alluded to in the Florence speech basically has a strong backing by her own party. And she must come out of this week in a way as someone who is, you know, sure to be the leader for the coming years, and then I think Brexit could take a more, you know, constructive path than it has maybe over the last past few months.

LACQUA: Christian, when you revise upwards or downwards your economic forecast for the U.K., do you look at BOE or do you look at Brexit talks, or both?

KELLER: We -- we look more at -- at Brexit talks in the sense that we look at uncertainty and what could happen to investment. At the moment, you know, we have a U.K. economy that has been much more resilient than people have thought. And you know, consumption has held up very well, and what we see now is, you know, investment in a way, slowing, and you know, the BOE will be important, they may be hiking, and that has an impact on the -- on consumers who pay mortgages, et cetera, but I think if we have an outlook for Brexit that signal some kind of a certainty, I think that would help the U.K. economy over the medium term significantly.

LACQUA: Have you -- are you a political analyst yet? You know, forget all this investment stuff.

SRINIVASAN: I can do politics.

LACQUA: Politics, right. Do you need to be like a political analyst to try figure out where you put money in the -- in the U.K. or in the U.S., or not?

SRINIVASAN: No, absolutely. But I think on Brexit, Christian has all the points right, I don't disagree with anything he said. My point is that, it's a complex issue, negotiating Brexit. I think you have to be incrementalist (ph) about it just because the Europeans are and the whole process is. And don't forget that Britain had about a 15-year up-cycle, barring that '07, '08 situation. So just from a cyclical point of view, having a slower U.K. is expected, and now, doesn't mean it's going to collapse, I just think they just expect slower growth in the U.K.

LACQUA: What happens to pound? And actually, if pound is weaker, does it make, you know, investments more attractive?

SRINIVASAN: Yes, pound was in a 1.20, 1.30 range, it's now broken out to 1.33, 1.34, I think it stays around here, and (inaudible) it pulled back a bit, but I think you've got a sterling which is essentially trying to find a base around 1.30, you know, 1.28, 1.30.

LACQUA: OK. 1.28, 1.30. Christian, first of all, what's your take on -- this is actually one of my favorite charts, and this is U.K. consumer credit, and it's something that I imagine Mark Carney is looking at very closely because of interest rates and the fact that households are so indebted in this country, does this chart worry you?

KELLER: Well, it is a chart that is important, and I think it is important also because it is behind some of the recent significant change in the attitude of the Bank of England. And if you go through particularly, what some of the MPC members who are considered to be dovish when they turn around in their view, they highlighted a balance sheet of the households and said, deleveraging of -- of households was over, and they have been leveraging, and this is why they argued for a rate hike because they believed they're now in a situation where households are level again, households are robust enough that they could withstand, you know, some increase in interest rates. So I think it's a very important chart and one -- one to follow. Not concerned really, I think, you know, the hikes will be -- we see one hike for now, you know, and I think the Bank of England will -- will act very, very cautiously.

LACQUA: OK. What's your take on -- on euro-pound actually? So you gave us a level on euro-dollar, is this the most interesting one?

SRINIVASAN: Yes, range bound, just range bound. Like a lot of currency, I think euro-dollar will be range bound, euro-sterling is range bound, I think you've got -- you got a period of uncertainty, in the U.K. it's Brexit, in Europe now, it's got Spain, Catalonia, et cetera, and of course, ECB policy, so I think between both things, I think you really got a range bound currency across.

LACQUA: OK. Interesting. I want to talk a little bit more about the global outlook now. Now, in a new report, Barclays has said U.S. growth remains decent if unexciting, while Europe and Japan have shown further upside. The bank expects the Fed to hike in December and twice in 2018, while the ECB is likely to taper further next year. Christian, this is your report, what's the most surprising thing in it?

KELLER: I think the most surprising in it is if you -- if you look at it again, you know, how well global growth is synchronized. And, you know, there's a lot of questions from investors who say, well, is this as good as it gets? You know, shouldn't one be more cautious now? You know, things have been going very well in particular, if -- if you look at equity valuation in the U.S. But we look at the data, and we see a global economy that continues to expand, where U.S. no longer the cyclical leadership, but we get very good data out of -- out of Europe. Japan's in the economy that has relatively low growth but is running above potential. We see some of the emerging markets like Russia, Brazil, coming out of deep recessions, and we see a China that you saw it over -- over the weekend, continues to hold up quite well. Now, this is something we haven't had for 5, 6 years, and it means, global growth running around 4 percent, and if you look at equity earnings, they correlate very well with global growth, and we think that is basically the -- the big story that is still there, and that's why we continue to be quite constructive.

LACQUA: Are -- are you -- are you positive about world growth or is it all based on air?

SRINIVASAN: This is the first time since 2007 that all -- all economies, 40 plus economies counted by the OECD, are showing positive growth, so I am very comfortable with growth.

LACQUA: How do you feel with inflation though? I| mean, there are -- there are still puzzles, right? And I don't know if it's the Phillips curve being broken or something more sinister out there.

KELLER: I think, you know, the -- the second part of the surprise is the - - in the data is basically that inflation stays so muted. The good thing is we are creating drops, so unemployment rates are falling in all the key economies, but we don't have the wage growth. Now, whether it's something sinister, I think there are several effect at work, one, it does take time. People are coming back into the labor market, you mentioned Italy earlier. There are people now coming back who were not in the Labor market, that's where the unemployment doesn't fall, because if the participation rates goes up. These are good developments, but I think there is something bigger in the background, that's technology, globalization, and that's why Phillips curves no longer work the way they did in the past, and that's something I think central banks have to grapple with because all their models and all their usual actions are based on, you know, the Phillips curve working.

LACQUA: And Nikhil, do you worry -- I don't know if you worry about inflation or do you just worry that for example, if you look at the most distorted market (inaudible) most probably the bond market, and so as this kind of, you know, gets re-priced, it could lead to further correction (inaudible).

SRINIVASAN: Yes, let's talk about this -- this inflation and this Fed policy, for example. Fed policy is all about normalization. I don't think that it really cares much about inflation as normalizing the interest rate situation.

LACQUA: OK. But should they care more about inflation?

SRINIVASAN: Well, they -- they want inflation. I think everything -- OK, if you look at global, you look at reflationary currencies, Aussie dollar, Canadian dollar, basic materials, copper, aluminum, all are pointing to more inflation, OK? We haven't seen it in the U.S., we haven't really seen it anywhere in the world right now, but at least --

LACQUA: Except for U.K.

SRINIVASAN: Yes. But things -- if I -- if I look at typical reflationary indicators are all up, but I said, the Feds behavior is about normalizing based on financial stability, it's not really based on well, inflation's going to hit X, and so we've got to do it now. And so the Fed will continue to gradually increase rates, OK? I think we'll get some inflation, probably get some inflation in Germany, it's been going very strong, probably get some inflation generally, in Europe, probably get some everywhere, but we're not going to get as much as people want, so when you look at yields and you say, OK, well, yields are 10-year U.S. at 2.36 today, where is it going? Look, it will go higher. I think all yields were high in the next 12 months.

LACQUA: All right. Guys, thank you so much. Christian Keller there, head of economic research at Barclays, thank you for your time. And Nikhil Srinivasan stays with us, we'll talk a little bit more about the risks out there, we had great comments from Crispin Odey as well. We'll talk about regulation and kind of China as well next.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Well, still with us, Nikhil Srinivasan, he is from HPS Investment Partners. Nikhil, when you look at the risks out there, so we had Mr. Odey actually quite bearish overall, right, about his view on the world economy. What do you see as the biggest risk out there for markets?

SRINIVASAN: I think the biggest risk, Francine, is complacency. I think people are complacent about the North Korean situation, they're complacent about the Middle East and the Kyrgyzstan independence vote and oil in general, and they're complacent in the U.S. about increased regulation on big Tech. So I think if you look everywhere, I think the biggest risk is complacency. People are saying, well, let's just keep going forward.

LACQUA: Why are they complacent? Is it something to do with algorithms and the way that the markets are actually right at the moment, or is it that it's impossible to, you know, price in Trump's next move, but also you're going to do with North Korea?

SRINIVASAN: Well, it's hard to value the level of risk that I'm talking about. So given it's hard to value the risk, given there's a lot of liquidity out there, given the Fed's policies, you know, I'd say that people just want to continue doing what they're doing and they've made money doing it, so you can't argue with that, right? So these are, if you ask me, the biggest risk is complacency because it's not priced in. Korea, it's not pricing in Korean risk.

LACQUA: What will it take to be priced in? I mean, is it kind of a snowball effect?

SRINIVASAN: Well, not necessarily. For example, if you are in the Big Tech stocks for example, I think they are not people -- they have come off a bit, I mean, they've come off relative to the market. I think people have to get used to the fact that these companies are going to face more of a (inaudible) going forward, but the ownership of these stocks remains extremely robust, and so you haven't seen a real selloff, 10 percent, but you haven't seen a real selloff for these companies yet, that's one thing.

LACQUA: Nikhil, do you worry about -- I mean, I don't know what actually your canary in the coal mine, you know, benchmark is, is there something? Will it come from China, or is it really impossible to predict?

SRINIVASAN: China's fine, Francine. So if you're talking about China, I think people shouldn't worry about China, they --

LACQUA: Not even the debt --

SRINIVASAN: No, nothing.

LACQUA: -- and reserves?

SRINIVASAN: Nothing. I think the currency has shown resilience, currency rallied in the last few weeks. I think the congress is going to go fine, I think you're going to have a slowdown of growth built in because of supply- side reform so they have -- have kicked in, built in because you have this anti-corruption move which is going to taper off. I think going into next year in the (inaudible) we see very, very growth -- good growth in China, I am not worried about China at all.

LACQUA: Are you worried about emerging markets and the fact that if Fed normalizes? It's been telegraphed for about three years, but are you worried about some kind of correction in emerging markets, just (inaudible) you know, technical Fed?

SRINIVASAN: Yes, well, because they -- they rallied a lot, so yes, they could correct. I mean, certainly, but I think China will continue to go up, and the Chinese market looks pretty good overall. I think all these emerging markets have run up quite a bit, most of them (inaudible). I would say I'm -- I'm less bearish or less worried about corrections from the oil markets like Russia. I think Russia has more upside as well. I think that, you know, you have to take -- take a step back and say, look, are we still looking at the world through the lens of '07, '08? And every time something happens, we can never tell there's a correction coming, corrections will come. Global economy is growing. It think the biggest uncertainties are the three things that I mentioned.

LACQUA: OK. But what about politics? Again, if you look at, you know, people voting in Europe for example, sure, GDP is getting higher, you know, joblessness is going down, but actually, one in 10 people voted for a far right candidate in the -- in Germany, they did the same in France.

SRINIVASAN: Well, there's -- there's economic inequity in Europe, just like it is in another parts of the world. Like, we saw that in the U.S., we're seeing that here as well, that's going to continue, that's not going away.

LACQUA: Will it get worse?

SRINIVASAN: I think it's going to get worse. But it's not going to get substantially worse, it's going to get worse in terms of (inaudible) voting patterns that continue to show people are disgruntled, at least a large or a visible part of the population is disgruntled. It's -- it's disgruntled here in the U.K., in Germany, in Spain, now you see it, in Italy, everywhere and around the world, so you're going to see that. you're going to see protest votes gathering pace. Now, that's going to impact policy, monetary policy, fiscal policy, you're going to see governments having to run deficits. The U.K. government will have to run their deficit. European governments have to run their deficit. Even the German government which is -- which is in surplus will incrementally have to increase spending on infrastructure and other things, incrementally, gradually, step by step, German style. I think everyone has to accept the fact that there are certain people in the population that are not really gaining from what is headline growth.

LACQUA: All right, Nikhil, thank you so much. Nikhil Srinivasan there, chairman international, HPS Investment Partners stays with us.

(BREAK)

LACQUA: Now, we were just talking with Nikhil Srinivasan, and we have a question from NIB, from a viewer, and this Nikhil is for you. Now, this is a question, we were talking of course, about complacency and the market's complacency, would you say that the complacency originates from the fact that the majority of the disgruntled are not amongst its players? So actually, does this disgruntlement, Nikhil, then -- then becomes something that we should worry about for markets?

SRINIVASAN: The question is fair. I think (inaudible) players is right. I don't think you have to worry about it is a constant something might happen, but I think it is, the consequence from a policy point of view is governments have to remain relatively loose in the fiscal front, that's it. And on the monetary side, you have to remain loose as well, so that's not - - you know, tightening's not going t to happen, it can't happen if you want the disgruntled to be feeling better off. And I don't think any economy in Europe can tighten today, or in the U.S. I don't think the U.S. can tighten. In fact, the tax cut plans are all going to be fiscally negative, right? Be expansionary, so no, I think fiscal policy has to remain expansionary.

LACQUA: OK. Which is why you were talking about normalizing, and actually, not tightening. The dollar has strengthened after reports that President Trump and secretary -- Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin have met with Kevin Warsh to discuss nominating him to succeed Fed chair, Janet Yellen. Nikhil, again, I guess for you, it doesn't really matter who's in charge next. I seem to understand about your comments that it will be kind of steady as she goes which is normalizing.

SRINIVASAN: Yes. I think my point about normalizing was less to do with inflation even though inflation is -- is the core of the Fed alongside employment, I'd say it's more to do with normalizing in General, to ensure financial stability. Ownership of U.S. equities among U.S. households has again, reached a high last seen 10 years ago, and I think the Fed must be concerned, and they must ensure that they don't have any - any accidents down the road, so I think that normalization is far from close.

LACQUA: Ok. But does it -- it still matters right, if you have someone at the head who's a dove or a hawk, because actually, how you interpret, I mean, you say they shouldn't focus too much on inflation, they just want stability, but so far, inflation has been the cornerstone of how you measure stability.

SRINIVASAN: Yes. But you see, every time they don't get inflation, they use another measure. They try and say, well, it's going to come, they could suddenly surprise you. Look, these are the comments with people who don't see inflation, yet want to raise rates.

LACQUA: OK, would you change the mandate? And if you would change the mandate for the Fed, what would you be looking at? I mean, you need metric, right, on - on how you look at it, otherwise, it's a free for all.

SRINIVASAN: I would look -- I mean, I look at something they can't probably include which is capital allocation because when you have a lot of free liquidity you misallocate capital, and that's what's been happening. You know, certain really been bid up, other things like capital investment has been ignore, so -- but I think you can't really change the mandate, that's not my point. My point is that, we were late to normalize, and now, they have to at least, reach a level of normalization they are comfortable with, which maybe, the market decide if that's too high, too low, but what they are comfortable with, and that means high rates.

LACQUA: Nikhil, what will be a game-changer for you in the U.S.? Is it all to do with monetary policy or does a tax cut for example, repatriation at 10 percent actually, significantly change the way you look at animal spirits U.S.?

SRINIVASAN: I think what would be a game changer if GDP in the U.S. really dropped, say, below 1 percent, which it doesn't seem at this point, likely.

LACQUA: So why would it do that?

SRINIVASAN: Well, because I think people aren't ready for that. People are ready -- people accepted a stable one and a half economy, or one and a half, two. People are not ready for something that comes closer to the zero to one, and I think that would surprise people, and that would show finally that, oh, my god, you know, something is wrong, we're not getting the growth they want, and I think that the --

LACQUA: But you think that's likely, or is --

SRINIVASAN: I don't think that's likely. At today's setting, I don't see it in the numbers. I can't say it's going to happen, but I'm saying that's your risk, you said , what's your biggest risk? That's my biggest risk, is GDP falling below expectation.

LACQUA: OK. But what would need to happen for that GDP to fall below expectations?

SRINIVASAN: Just people don't want to buy consumption falls, I mean, retail spending falls. I mean, these are, you know, oil prices, you know the issue. But again, if oil prices go up significant -- I think oil is in a good spot, I don't see we're going to $80, but I see oil pretty well-bid everywhere.

LACQUA: When you look at infrastructure plans, again, from the Trump administration, does -- does filter through GDP? I mean, it's unclear to me, even these tax cuts, at this point in the cycle, does it filter through inflation, or does it -- or does it work on GDP?

SRINIVASAN: I prefer tax cuts to infrastructure spending. Infrastructure spending is a bit like communism, it works well in theory, not always well in practice.

LACQUA: Because of lagging time?

SRINIVASAN: Just wastage, slippage, all kinds of things, you know. So the dollar spent on infrastructure doesn't really -- studies have shown infrastructure doesn't yield as much for GDP as tax cuts do, so if you ask me which one I'd prefer, I'd prefer tax cuts.

LACQUA: What's priced in at the moment in the market?

SRINIVASAN: I think tax cut, something's -- you -- one, Trump success is priced in, and I think it's going to be somewhat linked to tax cuts, which I think is -- is reasonable. I mean, there may be compromises along the way between the two parties, but I think that he'll get something, I'll be surprised if the president doesn't.

LACQUA: OK. Nikhil, when you look at I guess, the composition, you know, we talked a little bit about around the world, emerging markets, U.S., Europe, is it right to think that Europe will outperform the U.S.? I know we're starting from the very low base.

SRINIVASAN: No, no, for sure. I have no doubt that the -- Europe will (inaudible) the U.S. votes in terms of overall growth and also as well, markets. I'd rather buy European equities than U.S. equities (inaudible).

LACQUA: But equities are exposed globally, so you get, what, you get a discount because of European (inaudible) you?

SRINIVASAN: Well, I mean, yes. I mean, you know, European equities are both global and low, and I just say, baskets of European stocks are more appealing, I think you're going to have a looser policy directive from the ECB, you know, continued loose policy from the ECB, you're going to have continued loose fiscal from European governments, so Europe looks all right. I mean, you know, you can't call the end Europe, yen to Europe just a year after things have started to really dwell or two years (inaudible) a lot of the countries. Germany's been doing well for a long time.

LACQUA: It's Europe. Don't we do that every couple of years that it's the end of the world, and end of the -- end of the -- the experiment?

SRINIVASAN: You know, commentators in this country and the U.S. have been talking about the end of the experiment for a very long time, ever since the crisis, right, they've been wrong, and they're going to continue to be wrong about the end of the experiment, OK? The question then is, can Europe outperform? And Europe's sometimes its own worst enemy. It was too late in terms of loosening monetary policy, you've seen the consequences in Spain yesterday, you know, and so as long as things continue to chug along and, you know, the French-German relationship could just produce positive news for Europe. I think Europe continues to do fine. I think it's -- it's just -- it's a cottage industry to be negative on Europe all the time.

LACQUA: All right, Nikhil, thank you so much for joining us. We have to get you back on to talk about Japan as well, that's the only thing we kind of didn't do in our 60 minutes (inaudible). Nikhil Srinivasan there from HPS Investment Partners.

[*]

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
